abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            modest, the Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was satisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that reducing the time needed for careful
            preparation and increasing the size of the loan for
            project-external political factors was a decision that put
            the project at risk from the outset and was to a large and
            critical extent responsible for the factors that prevented
            the operation from attaining its objectives in terms of both
            development outcome and project output. As it was, the
            project was too large and too ambition in its objectives for
            the then context of Russia. A smaller pilot-operation type
            project with more modest objectives and a shorter duration
            would have had significantly better prospects of successful
            completion and achievement of outcome. Even though it was
            clear from an early point onward that the project would
            achieve neither its objectives nor output and disbursement
            targets, supervision efforts were primarily directed at
            keeping the project going or exploring alternative ways to
            increase disbursements. The resources spent on these efforts
            could have been more profitably used in the preparation of
            new operations responding to the actual needs of the sector.
            By discounting the problems of demand, especially given the
            then existing social and economic context of Russia, was a
            serious mistake. While not a foregone conclusion in that
            environment, a more balanced approach would probably have
            had better prospects of having a successful and lasting
            policy impact. While attractive, innovative and seemingly
            the most efficient solution for implementation management at
            the time of project preparation, the 'General
            Consultant' became a costly legacy and source of
            possible conflicts of interest.
